audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 19 and Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 19 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Baseball.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 67–92>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 171–190>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Inflectional endings with spelling changes. When adding a suffix, or word part, to the end of a word, you sometimes have to change the spelling of the word before adding the ending.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "like." Before adding the inflectional ending "ing" to "like," first drop the final "e." Now add "ing." What is the new word? <pause> liking. Try using the word "liking" in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns with each of the following: like like-e+ing liking (please show the "ing" in red font) run run+n+ing running (please show the "ing" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "run." Before adding the inflectional ending "ing" to "run," first double the final consonant "n." Now add "ing." What is the new word? <pause> running. Try using the word "running" in a sentence.

Listen as I read the following word: "hope." Before adding the inflectional ending "ed" to "hope," first drop the final "e." Now add "ed." What is the new word? <pause> hoped. Try using the word "hoped" in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns with each of the following: hope hope-e+ed hoped (please show the "ed" in red font) hop hop+p+ed hopped (please show the "ed" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "hop." Before adding the inflectional ending "ed" to "hop," first double the final consonant "p." Now add "ed." What is the new word? <pause> hopped. Try using the word "hopped" in a sentence.
Practice adding the suffixes "ing" and "ed" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "save" and "stop" and the phonics/syllable cards for "ing" and "ed">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about inflectional endings with spelling changes, let’s blend some words using these endings and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words table>

audio.transcription: /bāāāk/, bake. /bāāākt/, baked. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.' Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about homes around the world. First, look at these three pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. yurt <pause>, igloo <pause>, snow <pause>, dry mud and clay <pause>, adobe home. Look at the picture of the igloo. What is the igloo made of?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about homes around the world. The word is shelter. A shelter is a place that provides protection or safety.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, shelter>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, values>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Homes Around the World.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words shelter and values>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about homes around the world? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this story is "Country Mouse and City Mouse.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Country Mouse and City Mouse. This story has two different settings—the country and the city.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: perspective. Perspective is a way of thinking about something. Mom shared her perspective about how a new park would benefit the local community. What is your perspective on year‑round school? Are you for it or against it?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, perspective>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the sentence that tells why City Mouse wants to show Country Mouse the city.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: What is Country Mouse’s perspective on the city? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the city and country alike? How are they different?
Would you prefer to live in the city or the country? Why?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write whether City Mouse will visit Country Mouse again. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial, Medial, and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Country Mouse and City Mouse.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Substitute Initial, Medial, and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: toy
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word toy, but change the beginning sound. Change /t/, to /b/. What's the new word? <pause> boy
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: card
Say the word card, but change the ending sound. Change /d/, to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> cart
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the middle sound of a word. Listen as I say a word: mat
Say the word mat, but change the middle sound. Change /a/, to /ē/. What's the new word? <pause> meat
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "like." Before adding the inflectional ending "ed" to "like," first drop the final "e." Now add "ed." What is the new word? <pause> liked.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: like like-e+ed liked (please show the "ed" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Now repeat the steps from above and add inflectional ending "ing" to "like."
Practice adding the suffixes "ing" and "ed" to the following words:
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "skip" and "use" and the phonics/syllable cards for "ing" and "ed">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about inflectional endings with spelling changes, let’s blend some words using these endings and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words table>

audio.transcription: /bāāāk/, bake. /bāāākt/, baked. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.' Say the word nice and loud.
Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: almost, animal, around, body, color>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word almost. Say the word with me. Almost. The word "almost" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me a-l-m-o-s-t.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: almost, animal, around, body, color.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about ancient cave paintings. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. cave <pause>, bull <pause>, painting <pause>, stencil. Look at the painting in the picture. Why do you think the painting is in a cave?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about ancient cave paintings. The word is discovered. Discovered means “to find something unexpectedly.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, discovered>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, intact>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Ancient Cave Paintings”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words discovered and intact>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about ancient cave paintings? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this text is "Nature Homes.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Nature Homes. This comic is about unusual homes that use nature in their designs.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: inspiration. Inspiration is an idea, object, or person that influences someone. A beautiful sunset was the inspiration for the painter’s artwork. What do you do when you need to find inspiration for a story or art project?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, inspiration>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the words in the first paragraph that reveal the narrator’s feelings about the homes in the text.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: What parts of nature provided inspiration for Fallingwater? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What is surprising about the homes in Cappadocia, Turkey? Explain.
Which home would you most like to live in? Why?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List and describe the four homes from the text. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Nature Homes.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 2 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 67–92>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 171–190>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "clap." Before adding the inflectional ending "ing" to "clap," first double the final consonant "p." Now add "ing." What is the new word? <pause> clapping.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: clap clap+p+ing clapping (please show the "ing" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Now repeat the steps from above and add inflectional ending "ed" to "clap."

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about inflectional endings with spelling changes, let’s blend some words using these endings and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with -ing.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -ed.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word rip. <pause> Double the final consonant and add the -ed ending. What word did you make? Ripped.
audio.notes: <visual: show letter cards in e-pocket chart>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word rip<pause>. Now change rip to ripped. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with inflectional endings -ed and -ing and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 12-13>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with inflectional endings -ed and -ing. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word sitting. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word sitting>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: chatting/joking, dropped/hiked.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs chatting/joking, dropped/hiked>

toc.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus
Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 3 spread>

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Let's review inflectional endings. These endings change the tense of a verb, or action word. The "ed" ending shows that the action happened in the past. The "ing" ending shows that the action is happening now.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards ed and ing>

audio.transcription: Some words require spelling changes before adding the ending. For example, when the base word ends in the letter "e," drop the "e" and add the ending.

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Let's practice adding inflectional ending "ed" to a word. Listen as I read the following word: "smile." Before adding inflectional ending "ed", drop the final letter "e." Now add ending "ed." What is the new word? <pause> smiled.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: smile smile-e+ed smiled (show "ed" in red font) >

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Now let's practice adding inflectional ending "ing" to a word. Before adding the inflectional ending "ing" to the word "smile," drop the finale "e." Now add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of the word. What is the new word? <pause> smiling.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: smile smile-e+ing smiling (show "ing" in red font >

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Some base words require the final consonant to be doubled before adding the "ed" or "ing" inflectional ending.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: skip skip+p+ed skipped (show "ed" in red font) >

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "skip." Before adding inflectional ending "ed" to "skip," double the final consonant "p." Now add the inflectional ending "ed" to the end of "skip." What is the new word? <pause> "skipped."

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Before adding the inflectional ending "ing" to "skip," double the final consonant "p." Now add the inflectional ending "ing" to the end of "skip." What is the new word? <pause> "skipping."
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: skip skip+p+ing skipping (show "ing" in red font) >

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Practice adding inflectional endings "ed" and "ing" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words drop, note, hurry, and joke twice, once across from the phonics/syllable card ed and once across from the phonics/syllable card ing>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.
Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: eye, form, high, light, story.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word high. Say the word with me. High. Which sounds do you hear in one? /h/ /ī/. Blend the sounds together.
Spell the word with me: h-i-g-h. The letters "i-g-h" makes the long i sound in the word "high."
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: eye, form, high, light, story.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word bored.
Now write the word shipping.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Spelling Booster image>

audio.transcription: dined
skipped
bragging
creating
regretted
deciding

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this text is "The Birthday Party." Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Birthday Party. This is a comic. The speech bubbles. point to the character that says the words. Read the comic. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the comic with -ed and -ing endings and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: The first sentence is: Tom was jogging and almost tripped. Say the sentence with me: Tom was jogging and almost tripped. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: I smiled as they were dancing around the room. Say the sentence with me: I smiled as they were dancing around the room. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.

toc.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes
Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Birthday Party.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 4 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 67–92>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 171–190>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Let's review inflectional endings. These endings change the tense of a verb, or action word. Some base words need spelling changes when an ending is added to the word, such as doubling the final consonant.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ing" and "ed">

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "wrap." <pause> Before adding inflectional ending "ing" to "wrap," first double the final consonant "p." <pause> Now add ending "ing" to the end of the word. What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: wrap wrap+p+ing wrapping (show "ing" in red font) >

audio.transcription: wrapping. <pause> The inflectional ending "ing" can show that an action is happening now, so "wrapping" means that the action, "wrap," is happening now.

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Before adding ending "ed" to the word "wrap," first double the final consonant "p." <pause> Now add inflectional ending "ed" to the end of the word. What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following: wrap wrap+p+ed wrapped (show "ed" in red font) >

audio.transcription: wrapped. <pause> "Wrapped" is the past-tense form of the verb "wrap." Adding inflectional ending "ed" changes the tense of the verb.

slides.title: Morphology: Inflectional Endings with Spelling Changes

audio.transcription: Practice adding inflectional endings "ing" and "ed" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "change," "pin," "tug," and "score" once across from the phonics/syllable card for "ing" and once across from the phonics/syllable card for "ed">

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: helping, baking, mopping, cried, saved, jogged, eating, quitting, hoped. Now look at these two categories. This is the word helping. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put helping under? <pause> Yes, helping goes in the -ing category because the word helping ends with -ing. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words helping, baking, mopping, cried, saved, jogged, eating, quitting, hoped> <visual: show word helping> <visual: show the sorting cards ed and ing in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
"-ed" and "-ing" are common word endings. You may notice the -ed and -ing word parts in many words. As we read, let's look for words with -ed and -ing.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about different types of homes. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. house <pause>, door <pause>, yard <pause>, Amsterdam <pause>, canal <pause>, flowers <pause>, houseboat <pause>, Turkey <pause>, cave home <pause>, mountain <pause>, Australia <pause>, underground home. Look at the picture of Amsterdam. What do you see in the picture?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about different types of homes. The word is located. Located means placed or found.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, located>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, exterior>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Home Sweet Home”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words located and exterior>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about different types of homes? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this text is "Discover Your Neighborhood’s Past.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Discover Your Neighborhood’s Past. You will read an informational text about the history of neighborhoods.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: located. Located means “in a certain place.” The library is located next to the post office. Where is the grocery store located?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, located>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the phrase that tells the first thing you should do on a walk to learn about your neighborhood.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Who should you ask if you want to know more about what your neighborhood was like long ago? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How do neighborhoods change over time? Explain.
What buildings are located in your neighborhood? What are their purposes?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write one way to find out about neighborhoods in each box. You'll use these facts to write a summary of the text. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before writing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Discover Your Neighborhood’s Past” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 5 spread>

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: grand
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word grand, but change /d/ to /t/. What's the new word? <pause> grant
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's change the second sound in a word. Listen as I say a word: glue
Say the word glue, but change /l/ to /r/. What's the new word? <pause> grew
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "hop." Before adding the inflectional ending "ed" to "hop," first double the final consonant "p." Now add "ed." What is the new word? <pause> hopped.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: hop hop+p+ed hopped (please show the "ed" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Now repeat the steps from above and add inflectional ending "ing" to "hop."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word almost. Say the word with me: "almost"
Spell the word with me: a-l-m-o-s-t. The word "almost" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with inflectional endings and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 18-19>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with inflectional endings. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word baking. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word baking>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 6 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 67–92>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 171–190>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "hop." Before adding the inflectional ending "ing" to "hop," first double the final consonant "p." Now add "ing." What is the new word? <pause> hopping.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: hop hop+p+ing hopping (please show the "ing" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Now repeat the steps from above and add inflectional ending "ed" to "hop."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word animal. Say the word with me: "animal"
Spell the word with me: a-n-i-m-a-l. The word "animal" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story.

Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. almost, <pause> animal, <pause> around, <pause> body, <pause> color, <pause> eye, <pause> form, <pause> high, <pause> light, <pause> story.
audio.notes: <visual: show "almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "A ______ is an animal that ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "A [blank] is an animal that [blank]." Then show "almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this text is "A Neighborhood Map." Point to the word as you read the title with me: A Neighborhood Map. This map shows the buildings and streets in a neighborhood. Discuss the features of a map.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the map?
Draw and label a map of the school’s neighborhood.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
toc.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the text “A Neighborhood Map.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 7 spread>

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following words: "i" "will" <pause> "I'll." What differences do you see between the words "I will" and "I'll" ?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word cards "i" and "will" on the left and show the word card "I'll" on the right>

audio.transcription: "I'll" is a contraction. It is a shortened way of saying the two words "i" and "will." To form this contraction, remove the space between the words, and replace the letters "w" and "i" with an apostrophe. The apostrophe takes the place of the letter or letters that drop from the second word when it is shortened.

"will," "have," and "am" are common words used to form contrations. Contractions with "will" contain "apostrophe-l-l." Contractions with "have" contain "apostrophe-v-e." Contractions with "am" contain "apostrphe-m."
audio.notes: <visual: show the following, side by side: title: "contractions with will" card: " 'll" title: "contractions with have" card: " 've"> title: "contractions with am" card: " 'm">

audio.transcription: Practice forming contractions for the following word pairs.
audio.notes: <visual show the following word cards: they, have; she, will; I, am>

audio.transcription: Now let's review contractions with "'t" and "'s." Remember, Contractions with "not" have "apostrophe-t" and contractions with "has" and "is" have "apostrophe-s." Practice forming the following words into contractions:
audio.notes: <visual show the following word cards: cannot; it, is; did, not; he, is>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "hope." Before adding the inflectional ending "ed" to "hope," first drop the final "e." Now add "ed." What is the new word? <pause> hoped.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: hope hop-e+ed hoped (please show the "ed" in red font)>

audio.transcription: Now repeat the steps from above and add inflectional ending "ing" to "hope."

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with -ing.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -ed.

slides.section: Build Words with Phonemic Awareness Focus
slides.title: Blending Focus

audio.transcription: Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word spot. <pause> Double the final consonant and add -ed. What word did you make? Spotted.
audio.notes: <visual: show letter cards in e-pocket chart>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word spot<pause>. Now change spot to spotted. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about Abraham Lincoln's home. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Abraham Lincoln’s home <pause>, Springfield, Illinois <pause>, chimney <pause>, window <pause>, fence <pause>, door <pause>, steps. Look at the picture of Abraham Lincoln's house. What do you know about President Abraham Lincoln?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about Abraham Lincoln's home. The word is farewell. Farewell means “goodbye.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, farewell>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, maintain>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Preserving a Piece of History”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words farewell and maintain>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about Abraham Lincoln's home? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this text is "A Letter to the City.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Letter to the City. You will read a letter written by a boy to his city council.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: value. Value is the importance or worth of something. This necklace has value because it was a gift from Jada’s grandmother. What do you value the most? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, value>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the phrase that tells why the writer is upset.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: What would happen if Hill House is torn down? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Does the writer make a convincing argument? Why or why not?
Do you think that historic buildings add value to neighborhoods? Explain.
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a response to Mark Wang from the city council. <pause> Discuss your ideas with a partner before writing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the story “A Letter to the City.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 8 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards 67–92>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards 171–190>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review Inflectional endings with spelling changes. Some base words need spelling changes when adding the inflectional endings "ed" and "ing."
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "ed" and "ing">

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

slides.title: Use Dictation with Phonemic Awareness Focus

audio.transcription: Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word biked.
Now write the word scoring.
Finally, write this sentence: I spotted the bright eyes of a cat racing across the street.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about the Louisiana Purchase. First, look at the picture. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Louisiana Purchase <pause>, Pacific Ocean <pause>, Rocky Mountains <pause>, Canada <pause>, Mississippi River <pause>, Gulf of Mexico <pause>, Atlantic Ocean. Look at the map of the Louisiana Purchase. What oceans do you see?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about the Louisiana Purchase. The word is inspired. Inspired means “motivated someone to want to do something.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, inspired>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and word, territory>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The Louisiana Purchase”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words inspired and territory>

audio.transcription: Do you have any wonderings or questions about the Louisiana Purchase? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 20 Student Book. The title of this text is "Sacagawea.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Sacagawea. This informational text is a biography, or story about a person’s life.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: expeditions. Expeditions are trips with a specific purpose. Scientists go on long expeditions in forests around the world to discover, or find, rare plants and animals. Would you like to go on an expedition to another country? Where would you go? Why?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, expeditions>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Find the phrase that tells the purpose of Lewis and Clark’s trip.
audio.notes: <visual: show story>

audio.transcription: Who joined Sacagawea on the expedition? Find the sentence that answers the question.
Which details from the text support the claim that Sacagawea is famous?
Why do you think people still admire Sacagawea after hundreds of years?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a list of facts you learned about Sacagawea. <pause> Discuss your ideas with a partner before writing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 20, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 20.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 20 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Sacagawea.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: re-fused
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. Re-fused, refused.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: freezing
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Freezing, freez-ing.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

Let's review contractions with apostrophe l-l, apostrophe v-e, and apostrophe m. "will," "have," and "am" are common words used to form contrations. Contractions with "will" contain "apostrophe-l-l" and contractions with "have" contain "apostrophe-v-e" and contractions with "am" contain "apostrophe-m."
audio.notes: <visual: show the words: will, have, and am and the contractions: 'll, 've, and 'm in red>

audio.transcription: Look at the words "I" and "have." How would we form the contraction "I've" ?
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "I" and "have"

audio.transcription: Yes, we would remove the space and use an apostrophe to replace the letters "h" and "a" in the word "have" making the contraction "I've."
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "I" and "have" and under them: "I've"

audio.transcription: Practice building contractions from the following pronouns and verbs to see how many new words you can make.
audio.notes: <visual: show two columns of words, in the first column show: I, we, they, he, she; and in the second column show: will, have, am>

audio.transcription: Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
audio.notes: <visual: empty word ladder with 6 rungs>

audio.transcription: Write a word that names the sense related to your tongue.
Change the ending of taste to tell what someone did when they took a small bite of something.
Change the ending of tasted to describe what you do when eating food.
Change tasting to describe a dance that uses special shoes to make a tap‑tap sound.
Change tapping to tell what someone is doing if they are sleeping for a short time.
Change napping to tell what an audience is doing at the end of a show.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: almost, animal, around, body, color, eye, form, high, light, story>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "around."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: around>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 20!
audio.notes: <visual: show Cumulative Assessment page 30>
